Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the issue by stating that OSHA is not specifying any rules for employee safety, while OSHA actually issued advisory guidance on how employers can protect workers from COVID-19.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the claim.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that OSHA is not specifying which rules employees must follow or how to keep workers safe and healthy.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that OSHA is not taking any action to enforce worker safety guidelines, without providing substantial evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no alternative explanation bias present in the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that OSHA issued advisory guidance on worker safety guidelines for COVID-19.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering at times bias.
